column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Paint Stone
#Text=Breathe new life into your old home with a fresh coat of paint .
#Text=It sounds as easy as opening a can of paint and brushing it on , but there'r more to consider when you 're painting stone .
#Text=That does n't mean you ca n't paint over stone walls , foundations or chimneys that clash with the new new siding or furniture .
#Text=You can successfully paint any stone surface by preparing it properly through cleaning and priming and by adding eye-catching coats of paint with your sprayer or roller .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Preparing the Surface
#Text=Brush the stone to make it as clean as possible .
#Text=Use a wire brush to remove any dirt and make the surface you 're painting nice and smooth .
#Text=A good brushing will also remove any mineral deposits that may make your paint job look lumpy and uneven .
#Text=Wash the surface to remove grease .
#Text=Grease can show up anywhere , especially in the kitchen .
#Text=After you 've brushed away any large pieces of dirt , scrub the stone with a nylon brush or a sponge .
#Text=Use a mild cleaning formula such as dish detergent mixed with water .
#Text=Rinse the wall with clean water to remove any remaining debris .
#Text=While cleaning , check the masonry for cracks or other damage .
#Text=You may have to make repairs before painting .
#Text=Do n't just paint over problematic areas .
#Text=Spread primer on dry stone .
#Text=Primer is a sticky type of paint that 's often dull in color .
#Text=It 's made stick to surfaces so your top coat of paint goes on smoothly .
#Text=Use either a sprayer or a roller brush to apply primer evenly over the surface you plan to paint .
#Text=Sprayers are faster than brushes and can reach into uneven surfaces brushes miss .
#Text=They also take longer to set up and clean .
#Text=Brushes are slower , but it 's easier to apply primer evenly with them .
#Text=Choose a primer specifically made for stone to be sure your paint sticks properly .
#Text=Let the primer cure .
#Text=The primer needs to be completely dry before you start painting .
#Text=Once it 's dry , check to see if it 's covering the stone well or if you need to add a second coat .
#Text=If you have to add more primer , concentrate on the areas where the stone is n't as well-covered .
#Text=Clean your tools .
#Text=If you need to use the same tools to paint that you used for priming , you have to remove any residual primer from them .
#Text=Cleaning is necessary if you are n't using them so that the primer does n't dry and make them unusable .
#Text=Painting the First Coat
#Text=Choose your painting tools .
#Text=Different tools are better for different types of stone surfaces .
#Text=Special masonry rollers are designed to be extra fluffy so that they get into the deepest nooks and crannies .
#Text=Some stone may be so rough that you need to use a sponge dipped in paint .
#Text=If you 're painting indoors , be sure to protect your floors and furniture from drips by putting down dropcloths .
#Text=Use paint that 's intended for masonry .
#Text=Stone draws moisture from the ground and the atmosphere .
#Text=Avoid most oil-based paints .
#Text=They trap dampness , damage stone surfaces and fail quickly because they do n't allow moisture to escape .
#Text=Lime , mineral and high-end acrylic paints are good choices because they are breathable and let moisture out .
#Text=Paint with even strokes .
#Text=Start painting at the top and work your way down .
#Text=Dip your brush in the paint again if it starts getting streaky .
#Text=You want the paint to be applied thoroughly to the primer .
#Text=When you 're finished , check for any spots you missed and touch them up with a small amount of paint .
#Text=Use a ladder or scaffolding to reach high places so that every surface is covered .
#Text=Wear old clothes and a dust mask to protect you from fumes while you paint .
#Text=Curing the Paint
#Text=Wait patiently for the paint to dry .
#Text=The paint has to be completely cured before you start another project or you risk damaging the top coat .
#Text=Many types of paint take up to 30 days to fully cure .
#Text=By that time , the excess water in the paint has evaporated and the paint is hard .
#Text=Properly cured paint is very hard and unlikely to chip .
#Text=Apply a second coat .
#Text=You may need to go over the first coat of paint again to cover any spots you missed the first time .
#Text=A second coat of paint also makes the paint job last longer .
#Text=Use the same type of paint as before so that the color is uniform and it cures in the same way .
#Text=A second coat of paint deepens the color of your home so that it stands out .
#Text=Clean up when you 're finished .
#Text=After the second coat has cured , look around for any stray droplets of paint .
#Text=It 's best to wait until after all of your painting is complete so that you 're not cleaning up more than once .
#Text=Gentle cleaning solvents and a scraping tool like a razor can lift paint from many surfaces .
#Text=Wrap an old rag around the blade of a putty knife to make a scraping tool that wo n't scratch surfaces like granite countertops .
